A characteristically folksy Western, sprawling around in the post-Civil War rivalries between Union (Wayne) and Confederacy (Hudson, remarkably good). 

Wayne, discovering that the Union army is planning to cheat him on a horse-trading deal, decides instead to drive his herd down to Mexico to sell to the Emperor Maximilian; Hudson, meanwhile, is leading a wagon train of disgruntled Southerners to settle in Mexico at the Emperor's invitation.
[img]http://imagizer.imageshack.us/v2/1024x768q90/18/qbvf.jpg[/img]
Their odysseys converge, and when their arrival in Mexico coincides with the Juarez revolt, they decide that the good old US of A provides better choices than these pesky foreigners after all.

It's all stirringly traditional stuff, with a lively supporting cast, and made very easy on the eye by William Clothier's camerawork.

John Wayne and Rock Hudson star in Andrew McLaglen's big budget western about Yankee and Confederate colonels pulling together in Mexico during the chaotic period after the Civil War

The Undefeated isn't exactly a thoroughbred horse opera - it's not twitchy enough. But with its two leads oozing easy confidence, it's hearty, handsome and thoroughly entertaining
